items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #20
items.summary: We were up early and on the road shortly after 7am as we had a long drive ahead - 8.5 to 9 hours to get to Denver. It was pretty spectacular scenery all the way - starting with the drive north to Moab. Huge red…
items.content_html:
We were up early and on the road shortly after 7am as we had a long drive ahead - 8.5 to 9 hours to get to Denver.  It was pretty spectacular scenery all the way - starting with the drive north to Moab.  Huge red rock formations rising out of the ground of varying shapes.

We crossed from Arizona into Utah, and then eventually into Colorado.  After a very flat section, we ended up following the Colorado River for much of the way to Denver along Interstate 70.  Alan had warned us that I-70 can be very congested on a Sunday afternoon as people from Denver return from the mountains back to the city.  And indeed, there were a number of slowdowns, but overall it ended up being ok.  It seemed like we were driving through mountain passes for the last three hours or so - either up steep grades or down equally steep slopes with frequent warnings to trucks to use low gear, and check their brakes, and places for trucks to cool their brakes and to put chains on and off in the winter.

It was nice to see some fall colours too - yellow leaves against the green slopes and grey rock above.  Colorado is a beautiful state!

We arrived at our airbnb in Denver around 5:30.  It is very comfortable and is centrally located, so we are looking forward to spending a couple of days here!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #19
items.summary: Here is what our cabin looked like for last night at Bright Angel Lodge...it was small but very comfortable, and less than 100 yards from the canyon rim. We got back to the lodge and decided to take the Bright Angel Trail down into the…
items.content_html:
Here is what our cabin looked like for last night at Bright Angel Lodge...it was small but very comfortable, and less than 100 yards from the canyon rim.

We got back to the lodge and decided to take the Bright Angel Trail down into the Canyon.  We thought about trying to get to the canyon floor, but changed our minds when we realized that was a ten mile hike - that was just going down.  Lots of signs warned that coming back up takes twice as long - so we decided to just head down for 20-30 minutes and then head back up.  It is a series of switchbacks with steep drop offs, and we were glad we didn't go much further....

You can see the Colorado River in this photo...

We left the park around 12:30 and headed for Kayenta Arizona.  Smooth driving until we hit a town called Tuba City - a major traffic jam where we were stuck for two hours.  It seemed like some kind of Navajo event was going on with very little traffic control or organization so we inched along and finally got clear of it and arrived in Kayenta around 8pm local time (an hour later than California, two hours earlier than Ottawa).  Tomorrow we have a lengthy drive to Denver so hope to make an early start!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #18
items.summary: We left our hotel this morning around 9am and headed east towards Arizona. We stopped at a rest stop for lunch as usual. Some interesting landscapes along the way... We drove to the south rim of the canyon and had no trouble getting into the…
items.content_html:
We left our hotel this morning around 9am and headed east towards Arizona.  We stopped at a rest stop for lunch as usual.  Some interesting landscapes along the way...

We drove to the south rim of the canyon and had no trouble getting into the park (I had read online that on busy weekends it can take 45 minutes to 2 hours to get into the park).  We found our hotel - the Bright Angel Lodge - which is located on the rim of the canyon.  We have a small but comfortable cabin.  Parking is a challenge - there is no designated parking for the lodge and so if you find a spot, you keep it otherwise you might need to park a mile away!  We were lucky to get a spot close by.  We headed out on the canyon rim trail.  

The view is stunning - the canyon is about 5000 feet deep.  It is really hard to grasp the scope of it - and photos certainly don't do it justice.  It is a bit alarming to see what people will do at the edge of the canyon to get a good photo - going off the path and  posing at the very edge with their back to canyon, or sitting with their legs dangling over the side.

We walked for a couple of hours and watched the sun set and the light slowly fade from the canyon walls before heading back for dinner at a restaurant near the hotel and then back to our cabin.

Notice the people in the two photos below - helps give a sense of perspective.

A bit harder to see them in this one, but look closely at the top right corner....this is Mather Point where most people come look especially if they only have a couple of hours.

Tomorrow we plan to take a shuttle bus to other viewpoints of the canyon, and also hike a short way down the Bright Angel Trail into the canyon.  We don't plan to go far as coming back up will be much harder!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #17
items.summary: Mitch made bread early this morning and we had fresh bread, avocado toast, fruit, and coffee before we said goodbye and headed out on the road once again. We drove southeast about 6 hours, all on interstates or major highways. As we drove the landscape…
items.content_html:
Mitch made bread early this morning and we had fresh bread, avocado toast, fruit, and coffee before we said goodbye and headed out on the road once again.

We drove southeast about 6 hours, all on interstates or major highways. As we drove the landscape became more desert-like, although we did pass several fields of small trees - not sure what they are growing.  In another field we saw what looked like oranges growing.

In this photo you can see green growth on one side, and desert on the other.  We passed a number of canals bringing water to fields - clearly without irrigation not much would grow here.

We crossed a mountain pass - the Tehachapi Pass, but it was not as dramatic as the mountain passes into Yosemite.  

We arrived at our hotel in Barstow California around 4pm today and it's clear we are in th desert - here is the view from the window...

We are about two hours from Los Angeles to the southwest of us, and two hours from Las Vegas to the northeast.

We walked over to Panera Bread for supper - by then the sun was starting to set and the temperature was pleasant.  Tomorrow we hope to make it to the Grand Canyon!

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #16
items.summary: Today will be a short post as we had a quiet, relaxing day at Mitch's place. We did laundry in the morning, and Mitch made cornbread muffins for lunch. Mitch and I went to Safeway in the afternoon for a few groceries. I took a…
items.content_html:
Today will be a short post as we had a quiet, relaxing day at Mitch's place.  We did laundry in the morning, and Mitch made cornbread muffins for lunch.  Mitch and I went to Safeway in the afternoon for a few groceries.  I took a few pictures of Mitch's place, starting with his workspace where the google magic happens!  You can see his bike in the corner which is how he gets around Walnut Creek.

Here is the living room...

And here is the patio...

We went for a walk at night - still 25 degrees...

Here is the BART train rolling into the station...

And back to Mitch's place once again...here is a map of the condo complex - Mitch is #77,

We've really enjoyed our time here, and nice to be able to visualize where Mitch lives.  Tomorrow we plan to head to Barstow, California - about half way to the Grand Canyon.

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #15
items.summary: Yosemite - what a place! It dates back to President Abraham Lincoln declaring Yosemite federally preserved land, followed by John Muir leading the effort in 1890 to have Yosemite Valley and the surrounding area established as a national park. It's not hard to see why…
items.content_html:
Yosemite - what a place!  It dates back to President Abraham Lincoln declaring Yosemite federally preserved land, followed by John Muir leading the effort in 1890 to have Yosemite Valley and the surrounding area established as a national park.  It's not hard to see why approximately 4 million visitors come here each year - the views are spectacular, no matter where you look when you are in Yosemite Valley.

We left Rush Creek Lodge around 8:30 and drove into the park

We stopped at a couple of viewpoints along the way.

The most famous viewpoint is Tunnel View, where you can see the whole valley off in the distance.

There are so many places to stop and walk for a bit and take in the view.  

Even though it was off-season, the park was still very busy, and it was difficult to find parking spots.  We eventually found a spot and stopped for lunch.

We took a two mile hike to Mirror Lake.  The path threaded through some huge boulders.

There was a warning sign at the start of the hike...

Although it's called Mirror Lake - the lake bed is completely dry right now.  This is a combination of the time of year (lowest water flow in the fall) and an ongoing drought.  You can see on the rock in the middle of the lake bed what the normal water level would have been.

A mountain face is visible from here, and some could see climbers on the rock - my eyes weren't sharp enough to capture it.

We walked over to the Village Lodge for a cold drink and then visited the lower Yosemite falls on our way back to the van.  Again, very little water flow at this time of year.

We got on the road again around 4:30 to head home.  We took a different pass through the mountains home - it wasn't quite as scary as the one we took to get here!  Home about 8:30 pm - ready for bed!

Here are a few more photos from the day...

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #14
items.summary: We left this afternoon for Yosemite - Mitch driving and me navigating our way out of the Bay Area - quite a network of highways and plenty of traffic even on an early monday afternoon. Eventually we left built up areas behind and drove through…
items.content_html:
We left this afternoon for Yosemite - Mitch driving and me navigating our way out of the Bay Area - quite a network of highways and plenty of traffic even on an early monday afternoon.  Eventually we left built up areas behind and drove through farming country - thousands of almond trees, interspersed with canals to provide irrigation.  After heading south we turned east and headed into the mountains going through the Sonora Pass.  Apparently it is the second highest in California and it certainly felt like it!  You need your wits about you, and I would not want to drive it in the dark.

The road is basically cut into the side of the hill and climbs steadily upward.  A sign at the start suggests shutting of your air conditioning for the next five miles to reduce the strain on the engine.  We eventually arrived at Rush Creek Lodge, a beautiful spot a few miles west of Yosemite.  The lodge consists of several buildings including a restaurant, a lounge area and a pool and it is really pretty when lit up at night.

We had supper in the restaurant before heading back to our room and waiting for it to get dark so we could go check out the stars in Yosemite.

Around 8pm, we drove 30 minutes into the park to an open spot where we could see the stars.  There was quite a bit of moonlight so conditions weren't ideal, but we could still see quite a few stars.  You lay down on your back on the ground and wait for your eyes to adjust to the darkness (and hope there are no bears nearby looking for a bedtime snack).  I didn't get any photos of this as you really need a tripod to have a long exposure in order to see much of anything in the shot.

We headed back to our hotel for the night.  It is a very comfortable room, but the wall art is a bit disturbing!  I guess it fits with the mountain theme!

Tomorrow we plan to head in to Yosemite for the day.

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #13
items.summary: Another quiet day with no driving! Janet and I were up at 6 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 6:30 our time (9:30 Ottawa time). We also enjoyed Aaron's ministry session at 8:45/11:45 on Mitch's big screen. We walked about 15 minutes to…
items.content_html:
Another quiet day with no driving!  Janet and I were up at 6 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 6:30 our time (9:30 Ottawa time).  We also enjoyed Aaron's ministry session at 8:45/11:45 on Mitch's big screen.

We walked about 15 minutes to a spot called Heavenly Bistro for brunch.  A busy place and we had to wait a while to get seated, but it was worth it!  French toast, eggs, bacon and sausage - well fueled for the day!

Another beautiful day here - the weather seems pretty reliable at 20-25 degrees and sunny.  We took this bridge over one of the busy streets - it connects up with the BART - Bay Area Rapid Transit system.  Mitch uses this to get into the office in San Francisco, about 40 minutes away.

Lots of greenery and a pleasant place to walk around.  

We swam in the condo pool outside Mitch's patio and sat reading and enjoying the sun.  The palm trees seem impossibly tall - not sure how they stay up there!

Tomorrow afternoon we plan to head to Yosemite National Park with Mitch, about 3.5 hours away.  He has been there a couple of times before so can show us around.  We plan to stay overnight near the park and head back to Walnut Creek on Tuesday.

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #12
items.summary: Today was lovely quiet day at Mitch's place with no driving! We did all our laundry in the morning, and in the afternoon we went for a walk on the trails near his place. We followed the trail to a nearby park where there were…
items.content_html:
Today was lovely quiet day at Mitch's place with no driving!  We did all our laundry in the morning, and in the afternoon we went for a walk on the trails near his place.  

We followed the trail to a nearby park where there were lots of families and kids playing.

There was a little lending library on the way...

There were some beautiful roses along the way...

Mitch made scones this afternoon and we had them with tea.  For supper he made pasta with marinara sauce, and crepes for dessert - we are eating well!  Tomorrow we will be up bright and early at 6:30 to join the zoom meeting in Ottawa at 9:30 EST.

items.title: USA Road Trip - Post #11
items.summary: This morning we walked down the street from our hotel to a cafe that opened at 6:30 am to get coffee and a muffin. It was just getting light, and the main street looked very pretty. The coffee shop is an eclectic space filled with…
items.content_html:
This morning we walked down the street from our hotel to a cafe that opened at 6:30 am to get coffee and a muffin. It was just getting light, and the main street looked very pretty.

The coffee shop is an eclectic space filled with books, knicknacks, paintings and kayaks!  It is a shared space with a workshop where kayaks and other things are made in the back, with the cafe area in the front.

Janet was keen to check out a fabric shop, but as it didn't open until 10 and we wanted to get to San Francisco before supper, we decided to head out.

We drove south on highway 101 until we reached Humbolt Redwoods State Park.  There is a road through the park that runs parallel to the 101 called Avenue of the Giants.  We took this road, and stopped and did a 2 mile hike through a grove of redwoods - these trees are hundreds of years old, and some reach heights of 360 feet - the tallest living things on the planet.  The only way to get a sense of their size is to have someone in the picture for perspective.  Apparently these trees were slated to be logged early in the 1900s to make shingles and stakes for growing grapes, and a group of people banded together to buy up tracks of redwoods to prevent this. They considered that chopping these giant trees down for such utiltarian items was the equivalent of chopping up a grandfather clock to make kindling wood.  Eventually these areas were turned into state parks and the trees preserved.  

We ate our lunch at the visitors center there and then drove on.  As we got nearer to San Francisco, the hills were yellow/brown shades with green spots of trees. 

We crossed the Richmond San Rafael Bridge to get over to the Oakland side of the bay and headed into Walnut Creek where Mitch lives.  Lots of traffic and Janet drove while I navigated.

You can see San Francisco in the distance above the fog in the photo below, taken from the bridge.

We arrived at Mitch's place around 4:45 pm - so nice to see him again!

Mitch gave us a quick tour of the condo grounds - a beautiful spot.

Very happy to be safely here - we covered a total of 5905 kilometres to get here from Ottawa!  Now we plan to enjoy a couple of quiet days with no driving!
